                <p class="Theme-Byline h-align-right"><em>Written by Andrew Czyzewski for </em><a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/the-forum" target="_blank"><em>The Forum</em></a><em>, Imperial's policy engagement programme</em></p>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
        <div class="Layer--two FullSize FullSize--scrollChild FullSize--child Theme-BackgroundMedia Theme-BackgroundImage">

      <section id="group-section-978trq8hAv">
        <div id="section-978trq8hAv" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextSection Theme-Section-Position-2 Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-BodyTextColumn-Center Theme-Section-HasOverlay Theme-Columns--1">
          <div class="Layout Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__row">
              <div class="Layout__col Layout__col-lg-6 Layout__col-lg-center Layout__col-md-8 Layout__col-md-center Layout__col-sm-10 Layout__col-sm-center Layout__col-xs-12 Layout__col-xs-left Theme-Column">
                <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText">
                  <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText--inner">
                    <p class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Dropcap">Ever since the modern science of epidemiology emerged in the 19<sup>th</sup> century, misinformation has never been far behind. John Snow, one of the founding fathers of the field, accurately mapped various cholera outbreaks in London based on his theory of germ transmission through contaminated water pumps. Yet despite accumulating evidence to support his disease modelling, which was published and distributed in pamphlets, it was never accepted until decades after his death – with the ‘miasmists’ instead holding sway that foul air was the culprit . </p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                          <div class="Display--none Display--md-block"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxNzkxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjE3OTEiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiNGQ0ZDRkMiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                          <div class="Display--md-none"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxNzkxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjE3OTEiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiNGQ0ZDRkMiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                        </div>
                        <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize"><a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Snow-cholera-map-1.jpg" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer"><picture><!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]--><source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/z34ta8EReD/snow-cholera-map-1-landscape-1920x1791.jpeg"><source media="(max-width: 900px)" data-srcset="./assets/z34ta8EReD/snow-cholera-map-1-landscape-1920x1791.jpeg"><!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="./assets/z34ta8EReD/snow-cholera-map-1-landscape-1920x1791.jpeg" alt="An old map of cholera outbreaks in London circa 1854"></picture></a></div>
                      </div>
                      <figcaption class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                          <p class>Original map made by John Snow in 1854. Cholera cases are highlighted in black. (Image credit: John Snow / Public domain)</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="Display--md-none">
                          <p class>Original map made by John Snow in 1854. Cholera cases are highlighted in black. (Image credit: John Snow / Public domain)</p>
                        </div>
                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>Over 150 years on, we’re in the midst of a pandemic of a novel coronavirus, where misinformation and misrepresentation is perhaps more prevalent than it has ever been. This ranges from the completely outlandish and utterly unfounded, to well-meaning assertions or overclaiming on matters of genuine and ongoing contention – and everything in-between. </p>
                    <div>
                      <blockquote class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Blockquote">Sometimes a deliberate attempt is made to side-track or skew the process of learning. <footer><cite class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-QuoteCite">Dr David Nabarro, WHO Special Envoy on Covid-19</cite></footer>
                      </blockquote>
                    </div>
                    <p class>An example of the former is the false theory that the construction of <a href="https://www.wired.co.uk/article/5g-coronavirus-conspiracy-theory" target="_blank">5G infrastructure is in any way linked to the spread of coronavirus</a> or worsening of the resulting COVID-19 disease – which has absolutely no evidence to support it. Meanwhile, questions over the <a href="https://www.newscientist.com/article/2240288-do-face-masks-work-against-the-coronavirus-and-should-you-wear-one/" target="_blank">benefit of face masks for members of the public</a>, as well as the related issue of the <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2020/03/27/social-distancing-new-study-suggests-two-metres-not-enough/" target="_blank">distance that the airborne virus can transmit</a> from, rumbles on. Even more problematic to navigate are assertions about the efficacy of certain potential treatments, such as the anti-malarial chloroquine and its related compound, hydroxychloroquine. Reputable institutions are still conducting proper trials of these and other candidates, but to assert that they should have a central role in the pandemic at this stage is misrepresenting the facts – even if those assertions come from the <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/9/21209797/trump-chloroquine-hydroxychloroquine-medication-social-media-misinformation" target="_blank">President of the United States</a> or the opinions of a <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/french-doctor-leads-charge-for-treating-coronavirus-with-antimalarial-drug-11586629801" target="_blank">single outspoken doctor</a>.</p>
                    <h2 class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Heading-Large">Battling the infodemic</h2>
                    <p class>“With any outbreak and particularly with COVID-19, you’ve got ‘known unknowns’ and you’ve got ‘unknown unknowns’,” says Dr David Nabarro, who is Co-Director of Imperial’s Institute of Global Health Innovation and Special Envoy on COVID-19 to the World Health Organisation (WHO). “Sometimes information or guidance turns out to be not valid, despite good intentions. What you then do, on the basis of new information – the result of known unknowns and unknown unknowns becoming visible – is adapt quite sharply in order to continue trying to do good. Then there’s a different situation, where a deliberate attempt is made to side-track or skew the process of learning, which you could call disinformation. I think it’s important to make the distinction.”  </p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                          <div class="Display--none Display--md-block"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMjAwMCAxMzMzIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIyMDAwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEzMzMiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiM1NjhCQjkiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                          <div class="Display--md-none"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMjAwMCAxMzMzIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIyMDAwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEzMzMiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiM1NjhCQjkiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                        </div>
                        <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                          <picture>
                            <!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]-->
                            <source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/0aafKx37sE/653769nabarro-2000x1333.jpeg">
                            <source media="(max-width: 900px)" data-srcset="./assets/0aafKx37sE/653769nabarro-2000x1333.jpeg">
                            <!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="./assets/0aafKx37sE/653769nabarro-2000x1333.jpeg" alt="Dr David Nabarro sitting on a panel for the World Health Organisation"></picture>
                        </div>
                      </div>
                      <figcaption class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                          <p class>Dr David Nabarro (Image credit: UN Ebola Response)</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="Display--md-none">
                          <p class>Dr David Nabarro (Image credit: UN Ebola Response)</p>
                        </div>
                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>This underlines a key part of the problem – that the public is effectively presented with various sources of information, through different digital media platforms, sometimes from anonymous sources and other times from figures claiming to have some degree of authority or credibility. It can be difficult to discern fact from fiction. And most worryingly this happens with alarming regularity, and <a href="https://slate.com/technology/2020/03/armchair-epidemiology-coronavirus.html" target="_blank">spurious claims can gain incredible traction</a> with huge swathes of the public in matter of days, even hours. </p>
                    <p class>The upshot is that evidence-based science is more important than ever. In the absence of a vaccine or validated antiviral treatments, information and public health measures are the only tools we have at our disposal to stop transmission of the virus, prevent deaths and keep our health systems running. </p>
                    <p class>Yet the methodical, considered approach which underpins robust research can be difficult to fully enact at a time like this, when the situation on the ground is rapidly changing and data are constantly being updated. </p>
                    <p class>“Science is about having a hypothesis, putting it to the test and if it’s found not to be valid in light of experience, then you revise your hypothesis,” Dr Nabarro says. “That is the nature of discoveries, the scientific process. We never <em>prove </em>anything, we’re always focusing on finding things that don’t fit to our hypothesis or our models and adapting our models. That is the process of learning, which had been going on super rapidly in this outbreak.”</p>
                    <p class>Fortunately, experience of previous fast-moving pandemics helps enormously.</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay" style="opacity:0.9"></div>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section>
      <section id="group-Disease-X-19dIcp9u2T">
        <div id="Disease-X-19dIcp9u2T" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextOverMediaSection Theme-Section-Position-3 DisplayContainerHeight DisplayContainerHeight--minHeight DisplayContainerHeight--flex Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-Section-HasOverlay">
          <div class="Layout FullSize--fullHeight Theme-Layer-TextBlock Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__flex--xcenter Layout__flex--ycenter Theme-Layer-TextBlock-Container" data-scrollymoly-basis="true">
              <div class="Theme-Layer-TextBlock-Inner DisplayContainer--heightBasis">
                <div>
                  <h2 class="Theme-Title Theme-TextSize-small"> Gearing up for Disease X</h2>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="Layer--two FullSize FullSize--fixedChild FullSize--child Theme-BackgroundMedia Theme-BackgroundImage">
            <div data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true" class="FullSize--fullWidth FullSize--fullHeight Core--pointerEventsNone Lazyload Lazyload--isLoading">
              <div class="FullSize Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-InstantImage" aria-hidden="true" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,">
                  <source media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media InstantImage__img ObjectFit--cover" src="data:image/gif;base64," aria-hidden="true" width="50" height="28" alt style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
              <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-Picture" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/blwmYTRVeS/disease-x-landscape-750x422.jpeg 750w, ./assets/blwmYTRVeS/disease-x-landscape-1718x966.jpeg 1718w, ./assets/blwmYTRVeS/disease-x-landscape-2336x1314.jpeg 2336w, ./assets/blwmYTRVeS/disease-x-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg 2560w" type="image/jpeg" media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#C9215A">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/Q27N8UfElA/disease-x-portrait-750x1333.jpeg 750w, ./assets/Q27N8UfElA/disease-x-portrait-920x1636.jpeg 920w, ./assets/Q27N8UfElA/disease-x-portrait-1066x1895.jpeg 1066w, ./assets/Q27N8UfElA/disease-x-portrait-1080x1920.jpeg 1080w" type="image/jpeg" media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#C9215A"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media ObjectFit--cover" data-src="./assets/blwmYTRVeS/disease-x-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg" alt="Droplets of pink and blue ink under the microscope" style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
            </div>
            <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay Theme-Section-Dark" style="opacity:0.3;background-color:#000000"></div>
          </div>
        </div>
        <div id="section-cqRsZyaHxg" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextSection Theme-Section-Position-4 Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Light Theme-BodyTextColumn-Center Theme-Section-HasOverlay Theme-Columns--1">
          <div class="Layout Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__row">
              <div class="Layout__col Layout__col-lg-6 Layout__col-lg-center Layout__col-md-8 Layout__col-md-center Layout__col-sm-10 Layout__col-sm-center Layout__col-xs-12 Layout__col-xs-left Theme-Column">
                <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText">
                  <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText--inner">
                    <p class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Dropcap">Imperial’s expertise in the field of disease and outbreak planning is genuinely world-leading. Researchers from the College have previously worked on outbreaks and pandemics, including SARS, bird flu, swine flu, MERS and Ebola. </p>
                    <p class>Expertise is now chiefly delivered through the <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/mrc-global-infectious-disease-analysis" target="_blank">MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis</a> (MRC GIDA) and <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/jameel-institute/" target="_blank">Abdul Latif Jameel Institute for Disease and Emergency Analytics</a> (J-IDEA), both based in the <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/school-public-health" target="_blank">School of Public Health</a>, but also various groups across the College.</p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                          <div class="Display--none Display--md-block"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxMjgwIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEyODAiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiMyNTJBM0MiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                          <div class="Display--md-none"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxMjgwIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEyODAiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiMyNTJBM0MiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                        </div>
                        <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                          <picture>
                            <!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]-->
                            <source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/j0OeaszaAS/ehbbomkwsae3gms-landscape-1920x1280.jpeg">
                            <source media="(max-width: 900px)" data-srcset="./assets/j0OeaszaAS/ehbbomkwsae3gms-landscape-1920x1280.jpeg">
                            <!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="./assets/j0OeaszaAS/ehbbomkwsae3gms-landscape-1920x1280.jpeg" alt="The founding members of J-IDEA"></picture>
                        </div>
                      </div>
                      <figcaption class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                          <p class>J-IDEA launch (October 2019.) Left to right, back row to front row: Professor Timothy Hallett; Professor Edward Gregg; Professor Helen Ward; Professor Majid Ezzati; Professor Neil Ferguson; Fady Jameel; Hassan Jameel; Dr Katharina Hauck; Professor Alice Gast; Mohammed Jameel </p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="Display--md-none">
                          <p class>J-IDEA launch (October 2019.) Left to right, back row to front row: Professor Timothy Hallett; Professor Edward Gregg; Professor Helen Ward; Professor Majid Ezzati; Professor Neil Ferguson; Fady Jameel; Hassan Jameel; Dr Katharina Hauck; Professor Alice Gast; Mohammed Jameel </p>
                        </div>
                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>In 2018, the WHO added a new item to its watchlist of threats, the ominously and portentously named <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/world-health-organization-issues-alert-disease-x/" target="_blank">‘Disease X’</a> which ‘represents the knowledge that a serious international epidemic could be caused by a pathogen currently unknown to cause human disease’. </p>
                    <div>
                      <blockquote class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Blockquote">We don’t know when it will come, but we know it will come<footer><cite class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-QuoteCite"></cite></footer>
                      </blockquote>
                    </div>
                    <p class>Dr Nabarro has held leadership roles on outbreak and pandemic response and planning at both the United Nations and the WHO - dating back to 2005 as UN System Senior Coordinator for Avian and Human Influenza. He said of Disease X:</p>
                    <p class>“Among a community of us, the inevitability of a major pandemic was definitely there. Our line was ‘we don’t know when it will come but we know it will come’. However, that perception was not necessarily felt by everybody.  Although a pandemic would always appear in analyses of global risks, there was a big uncertainly about its timing and its nature.  That has made it hard for governments to invest significantly in preparedness. There seems to have been a reduction in the expectation of a pandemic in some quarters in more recent years.  This is for a mix of reasons, but there has been a general sense that science would be able to get on top of any disease threats that might emerge.”</p>
                    <p class>In December 2018, Imperial and the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations formed a <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/189447/tailor-made-disease-vaccines-created-million-project/" target="_blank">partnership to help protect against Disease X</a>.</p>
                    <p class>Then in late 2019, <a href="http://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/196659/the-disease-outbreak-centre-where-scientists/" target="_blank">J-IDEA</a> was setup to rapidly respond to emergencies such as pandemics, extreme climate events, and natural and humanitarian disasters. Just weeks after J-IDEA launched, reports of the first cases of a novel coronavirus emerged from Asia.</p>
                    <div>
                      <blockquote class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Blockquote">Modelling isn’t a case of just pressing a button, it requires quite a lot of scientific input<footer><cite class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-QuoteCite">Professor Azra Ghani, Chair in Infectious Disease Epidemiology</cite></footer>
                      </blockquote>
                    </div>
                    <p class>Since January, the MRC-GIDA and J-IDEA teams have responded rapidly to the emerging coronavirus threat as the Imperial College COVID-19 Response Team – led by Professor Neil Ferguson alongside other world-leading professors including Christl Donnelly, Azra Ghani and Steven Riley, and later joined by Nick Grassly, Timothy Hallett and Katharina Hauck.</p>
                    <p class>Professor Ghani, who is Chair in Infectious Disease Epidemiology, says: “It started when we saw the first cases emerging from China. Early on we were thinking about what information we could get and that actually required an awful lot of scraping data from various websites, including the Ministry of Health website in China and regional websites [in the country]. We got together a very large team to do that. Once cases started to emerge outside of China, we kept track of these, looking at when they flew from China and returned home, to get some sense of when they must have been infected and the time between being infected and developing symptoms.”</p>
                    <div class="InlineMedia InlineMedia-Soundcloud">
                      <div data-soundcloud="true" class="SoundCloudPlayer SoundCloudPlayer--initializing" data-height="126" data-src="https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=https://soundcloud.com/user-499485249/crunching-the-numbers-for-coronavirus&auto_play=false&buying=true&liking=true&download=true&sharing=true&show_artwork=true&show_comments=true&show_playcount=true&show_user=true&hide_related=false&visual=true&start_track=0&callback=true"></div>
                      <div class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <p class></p>
                      </div>
                    </div>
                    <p class><sub><em>(Listen above to Professor Azra Ghani (Chair in infectious disease epidemiology at Imperial) giving insights into how mathematical models are providing vital insights into the nature of the outbreak.)</em></sub></p>
                    <p class>Epidemiological disease modelling is perhaps the central supporting pillar that allows public health officials to plan societal interventions. Imperial’s teams have developed and refined the computer code that underpins their epidemiological models over several years, through previous epidemics. That work has been published widely and validated externally. The models have also be used in pandemic planning and simulation scenarios. Nevertheless, when a pandemic of the magnitude of coronavirus hits, there is still considerable work to be done and new data to incorporate.</p>
                    <p class>Professor Ghani explains: “Early on in the pandemic, there was an agreement amongst funders and academic journals, which led to a huge amount of information being put up on websites and it is challenging even for those of us in this field of academic research to search through these. The only way we can really approach it is to have a very large team of people, including PhD and postdoctoral researchers – performing data entry or reading a paper and summarising it, trying to give us the best possible sense of all the scientific information that’s out there.</p>
                    <p class>“A lot of the tools are there, but what we find is that every little aspect of a new disease is slightly different: the data will have a slightly different format or the statistics that we need to use must be very slightly modified. So whilst we have a lot of this machinery ready to go, it isn’t really a case of just pressing a button, it requires quite a lot of scientific input.”</p>
                    <p class>The Imperial team has published <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/mrc-global-infectious-disease-analysis/covid-19/" target="_blank">regular reports</a> detailing the latest outputs from their epidemiological models. As one of the most prominent academic teams on the UK government’s Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (SAGE) and Science and Technology Committee, these have had a significant influence on policy. </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay" style="opacity:0.9"></div>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>

              <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                <p class>Suppression strategy scenarios for GB showing ICU bed requirements. The black line shows the unmitigated epidemic. The orange line shows a containment strategy incorporating case isolation, household quarantine and population-wide social distancing. The red line is the estimated surge ICU bed capacity in GB.         <div id="section-AS4CCxFFry" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextSection Theme-Section-Position-6 Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Light Theme-BodyTextColumn-Center Theme-Section-HasOverlay Theme-Columns--1">
          <div class="Layout Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__row">
              <div class="Layout__col Layout__col-lg-6 Layout__col-lg-center Layout__col-md-8 Layout__col-md-center Layout__col-sm-10 Layout__col-sm-center Layout__col-xs-12 Layout__col-xs-left Theme-Column">
                <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText">
                  <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText--inner">
                    <p class><a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/media/imperial-college/medicine/mrc-gida/2020-03-16-COVID19-Report-9.pdf" target="_blank">A landmark report published on the 16 March</a> detailed the latest results of the model, showing that extensive social distance and quarantine measures would be required to supress transmission, retain vital capacity in intensive care units and keep the number of fatalities to around 20,000. Without these strict measures the NHS would have been totally overwhelmed, with fatalities between 200,000 and 500,000, according to the models.</p>
                    <p class>The team continues to publish reports as new data become available for analysis – attempting to strike a balance between the rigorous, methodical scientific method and the pressing public and government need for new information. </p>
                    <p class>As well as publishing rapid response reports, the Imperial College COVID-19 Response Team has continued to work on deep analysis, publishing in <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/196573/covid-19-one-five-over-80s-need-hospitalisation/" target="_blank">peer-reviewed journals.</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay" style="opacity:0.9"></div>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section>
      <section id="group-Incubation-of-misinformation-cuPd9rV3f0">
        <div id="Incubation-of-misinformation-cuPd9rV3f0" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextOverMediaSection Theme-Section-Position-7 DisplayContainerHeight DisplayContainerHeight--minHeight DisplayContainerHeight--flex Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-Section-HasOverlay">

              <div class="Theme-Layer-TextBlock-Inner DisplayContainer--heightBasis">
                <div>
                  <h2 class="Theme-Title Theme-TextSize-small"> The incubation of misinformation during lockdown</h2>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="Layer--two FullSize FullSize--fixedChild FullSize--child Theme-BackgroundMedia Theme-BackgroundImage">
            <div data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true" class="FullSize--fullWidth FullSize--fullHeight Core--pointerEventsNone Lazyload Lazyload--isLoading">
              <div class="FullSize Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-InstantImage" aria-hidden="true" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,">
                  <source media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media InstantImage__img ObjectFit--cover" src="data:image/gif;base64," aria-hidden="true" width="50" height="28" alt style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
              <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-Picture" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/3qMYn44REq/incubation-landscape-750x422.jpeg 750w, ./assets/3qMYn44REq/incubation-landscape-1514x852.jpeg 1514w, ./assets/3qMYn44REq/incubation-landscape-2077x1168.jpeg 2077w, ./assets/3qMYn44REq/incubation-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg 2560w" type="image/jpeg" media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#252126">

        </div>
        <div id="section-BIniaHJuDI" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextSection Theme-Section-Position-8 Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-BodyTextColumn-Center Theme-Section-HasOverlay Theme-Columns--1">
          <div class="Layout Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__row">
              <div class="Layout__col Layout__col-lg-6 Layout__col-lg-center Layout__col-md-8 Layout__col-md-center Layout__col-sm-10 Layout__col-sm-center Layout__col-xs-12 Layout__col-xs-left Theme-Column">
                <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText">
                  <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText--inner">
                    <p class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Dropcap">With the implementation of lockdown in the UK and the full extent of the necessary social suppression measures being felt, this seemed to coincide with, and perhaps fuel, a new wave of misinformation. Around two weeks into lockdown, reports of attacks on 5G towers in the UK began to surface, spurred by some of those unfounded conspiracy theories. </p>
                    <p class>Imperial’s models also came in for more scrutiny from the mainstream media, as well as the radical fringes. Some commentators sought to downplay the severity of the pandemic, portraying Imperial’s models as ‘doomsday scenarios’ and the resulting lockdown measures as unnecessary. Despite the fact that the models are in broad agreement with those used in other countries.</p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                          <div class="Display--none Display--md-block"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMjU2MCAxNDQwIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIyNTYwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjE0NDAiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiMwNDA0MDIiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                          <div class="Display--md-none"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMjU2MCAxNDQwIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIyNTYwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjE0NDAiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiMwNDA0MDIiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                        </div>
                        <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                          <picture>
                            <!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]-->
                            <source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/17xzPWah7O/5g-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg">
                            <source media="(max-width: 900px)" data-srcset="./assets/17xzPWah7O/5g-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg">
                            <!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="./assets/17xzPWah7O/5g-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg" alt="'5G' on the screen of a smartphone, and a coronavirus icon in the background"></picture>
                        </div>
                      </div>
                      <figcaption class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                          <p class>False theories about the virus abound, such as that the construction of 5G infrastructure is in any way linked to the spread of coronavirus or worsening of the resulting COVID-19 disease </p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="Display--md-none">
                          <p class>False theories about the virus abound, such as that the construction of 5G infrastructure is in any way linked to the spread of coronavirus or worsening of the resulting COVID-19 disease </p>
                        </div>
                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>On 26 March, Professor Ferguson <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/196477/j-ideas-neil-ferguson-tells-mps-lockdown/" target="_blank">gave evidence</a>, via video link, to the UK’s Science and Technology Committee. With the suppression measures the team recommended now firmly in place and being enforced and largely abided by, he reiterated that the NHS should have the capacity to cope and that deaths should not be higher than 20,000, if measures continue to be abided by. </p>
                    <p class>Some portrayed that as a <a href="https://thefederalist.com/2020/03/26/the-scientist-whose-doomsday-pandemic-model-predicted-armageddon-just-walked-back-the-apocalyptic-predictions/" target="_blank">radical revision</a>, citing the 500,000 fatalities figure included in the March 16 report (along with the 20,000 figure). It perhaps stems from a lack of understanding that models can produce a variety of different output predictions based on the parameters and assumptions of the model – which in this case included various levels of social distancing and quarantine measures.</p>
                    <p class>It’s perhaps understandable, and in some cases excusable, that there is confusion and misinformation, after all this is an unprecedented and complex pandemic and many of us have had to get to grips with entirely new concepts and scientific lexicon: ‘flattening the curve’; basic reproduction number (R0); incubation times; and herd immunity, among many others.</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay" style="opacity:0.9"></div>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section>
      <section id="group-Building-trust-HL1w4IWyjB">
        <div id="Building-trust-HL1w4IWyjB" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextOverMediaSection Theme-Section-Position-9 DisplayContainerHeight DisplayContainerHeight--minHeight DisplayContainerHeight--flex Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-Section-HasOverlay">
          <div class="Layout FullSize--fullHeight Theme-Layer-TextBlock Layer--one">

              <div class="Theme-Layer-TextBlock-Inner DisplayContainer--heightBasis">
                <div>
                  <h2 class="Theme-Title Theme-TextSize-small"> Building trust within communities going forward</h2>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="Layer--two FullSize FullSize--fixedChild FullSize--child Theme-BackgroundMedia Theme-BackgroundImage">
            <div data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true" class="FullSize--fullWidth FullSize--fullHeight Core--pointerEventsNone Lazyload Lazyload--isLoading">
              <div class="FullSize Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-InstantImage" aria-hidden="true" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,">
                  <source media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media InstantImage__img ObjectFit--cover" src="data:image/gif;base64," aria-hidden="true" width="50" height="28" alt style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
              <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-Picture" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/n1saOUIdeB/trust-landscape-750x422.jpeg 750w, ./assets/n1saOUIdeB/trust-landscape-1740x979.jpeg 1740w, ./assets/n1saOUIdeB/trust-landscape-2399x1349.jpeg 2399w, ./assets/n1saOUIdeB/trust-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg 2560w" type="image/jpeg" media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#121210">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/oOG4bDO9Mc/trust-portrait-750x1333.jpeg 750w, ./assets/oOG4bDO9Mc/trust-portrait-940x1671.jpeg 940w, ./assets/oOG4bDO9Mc/trust-portrait-1034x1838.jpeg 1034w, ./assets/oOG4bDO9Mc/trust-portrait-1080x1920.jpeg 1080w" type="image/jpeg" media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#121210"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media ObjectFit--cover" data-src="./assets/n1saOUIdeB/trust-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg" alt="A busy city street at twilight in the rain" style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
            </div>
            <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay Theme-Section-Dark" style="opacity:0.45;background-color:#000000"></div>
          </div>
        </div>
        <div id="section-5dScKqVz04" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextSection Theme-Section-Position-10 Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Light Theme-BodyTextColumn-Center Theme-Section-HasOverlay Theme-Columns--1">
          <div class="Layout Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__row">
              <div class="Layout__col Layout__col-lg-6 Layout__col-lg-center Layout__col-md-8 Layout__col-md-center Layout__col-sm-10 Layout__col-sm-center Layout__col-xs-12 Layout__col-xs-left Theme-Column">
                <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText">
                  <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText--inner">
                    <p class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Dropcap">There is a strong likelihood that we are all going to have to live with and <a href="https://www.4sd.info/wp-content/uploads/200403-Narrative-Fifteen-A-COVID-19-READY-STATE.pdf" target="_blank">adapt to the reality of COVID</a> for some time to come – perhaps even years. After the initial spikes have peaked and transmission is under control, there will continue be sporadic outbreaks. </p>
                    <div>
                      <blockquote class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Blockquote">This will require a new style of public health, almost akin to a neighbourhood watch scheme<footer><cite class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-QuoteCite">Dr David Nabarro, WHO Special Envoy on Covid-19</cite></footer>
                      </blockquote>
                    </div>
                    <p class>The development of a vaccine will have an important role to play and several teams, <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/195055/imperial-researchers-race-develop-coronavirus-vaccine/" target="_blank">including a group at Imperial</a> are actively working towards that goal. Yet that will take some time to roll out on a large scale, and Dr Nabarro says that the role of communities will continue be absolutely essential in preventing larger flare-ups. </p>
                    <p class>“The only way to deal with this is to find outbreaks of the disease as they start and to really close them down by prompt action in communities. If you can do that, then life can go on, but this will require a new style of public health, almost akin to a neighbourhood watch scheme. That requires a really informed population.”</p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image h-align-center" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                          <div class="Display--none Display--md-block"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxMjgwIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEyODAiPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiM4NDg1N0MiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">

                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>

                        <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                          <picture>
                            <!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]-->
                            <source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/uXC8VMSGyP/lab-landscape-1920x1280.jpeg">
                            <source media="(max-width: 900px)" data-srcset="./assets/uXC8VMSGyP/lab-landscape-1920x1280.jpeg">
                            <!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="./assets/uXC8VMSGyP/lab-landscape-1920x1280.jpeg" alt="A female scientist using a centrifuge"></picture>
                        </div>
                      </div>
                      <figcaption class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                          <p class>Imperial's Department of Infectious Disease is one of several research groups around the world currently working to create a viable vaccine. (Image credit: Thomas Angus, Imperial College London)</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="Display--md-none">
                          <p class>Imperial's Department of Infectious Disease is one of several research groups around the world currently working to create a viable vaccine. (Image credit: Thomas Angus, Imperial College London)</p>
                        </div>
                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>Important lessons were learned during the Ebola outbreak of 2014 in West Africa, as well as during subsequent flare-ups. There was widespread mistrust of government, and also a belief in some quarters that Ebola didn’t really exist, that it was a hoax by the government to gain aid money or that people were being taken to treatment centres for organ harvesting. There was also an issue around traditional burial and funeral rites, which were contributing to ongoing disease transmission. Dr Nabarro served as UN Special Envoy on Ebola at the time. </p>
                    <p class>“We had to not only encourage people to trust those responsible for outbreak control but we had to learn to trust them too. This meant sharing the challenge with community leaders. We found that once they understood what we were saying and why, they were able to convey it to their people and implement behaviour changes in their way. We’re finding the same in Kenya with COVID – religious leaders are playing a vital role in sharing the message about transmission. Similarly in Egypt and other parts of the Middle East the mosques are so important.”</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay" style="opacity:0.9"></div>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section>
      <section id="group-Engagement-and-education-btV0kWTkn6">
        <div id="Engagement-and-education-btV0kWTkn6" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextOverMediaSection Theme-Section-Position-11 DisplayContainerHeight DisplayContainerHeight--minHeight DisplayContainerHeight--flex Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-Section-HasOverlay">
          <div class="Layout FullSize--fullHeight Theme-Layer-TextBlock Layer--one">

              <div class="Theme-Layer-TextBlock-Inner DisplayContainer--heightBasis">
                <div>
                  <h2 class="Theme-Title Theme-TextSize-small"> Addressing misinformation through engagement and education</h2>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="Layer--two FullSize FullSize--fixedChild FullSize--child Theme-BackgroundMedia Theme-BackgroundImage">
            <div data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true" class="FullSize--fullWidth FullSize--fullHeight Core--pointerEventsNone Lazyload Lazyload--isLoading">
              <div class="FullSize Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-InstantImage" aria-hidden="true" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,">
                  <source media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media InstantImage__img ObjectFit--cover" src="data:image/gif;base64," aria-hidden="true" width="50" height="28" alt style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
              <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-Picture" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/tUtYYVNZFy/engagement-landscape-750x422.jpeg 750w, ./assets/tUtYYVNZFy/engagement-landscape-1651x929.jpeg 1651w, ./assets/tUtYYVNZFy/engagement-landscape-2163x1217.jpeg 2163w, ./assets/tUtYYVNZFy/engagement-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg 2560w" type="image/jpeg" media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#054AC0">

        <div id="section-sl27ZVLpT1" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextSection Theme-Section-Position-12 Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-BodyTextColumn-Center Theme-Section-HasOverlay Theme-Columns--1">
          <div class="Layout Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__row">
              <div class="Layout__col Layout__col-lg-6 Layout__col-lg-center Layout__col-md-8 Layout__col-md-center Layout__col-sm-10 Layout__col-sm-center Layout__col-xs-12 Layout__col-xs-left Theme-Column">
                <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText">
                  <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText--inner">
                    <p class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Dropcap">In the current pandemic, Imperial researchers have themselves also been examining aspects of trust, engagement and misinformation, notably through the work of the <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/patient-experience-research-centre/" target="_blank">Patient Experience Research Centre</a> (PERC) – a multidisciplinary group of clinicians, public health specialists and social scientists combining strengths in quantitative and qualitative research methods. </p>
                    <div>
                      <blockquote class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Blockquote">We feel this is an important step in building trust between researchers, public health responders and local people.<footer><cite class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-QuoteCite">Professor Helen Ward, Director of the PERC</cite></footer>
                      </blockquote>
                    </div>
                    <p class>As part of Imperial's response to COVID-19, the <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/196696/coronavirus-misinformation-vaccine-research-among-priorities/" target="_blank">PERC has been exploring people’s views</a>, experiences and behavioural responses to the outbreak in the UK and elsewhere. The team has launched an online community involvement initiative to gather insight from members of the public, aiming to establish a network for ongoing community engagement. </p>
                    <p class>Online surveys revealed that information overload and conflicting guidance are among the biggest concerns for the public during the current coronavirus outbreak.</p>
                    <p class>Director of the PERC, Professor Helen Ward, said: "Building on our existing relationships with the public and patient groups we have been running online engagement activities to help guide our research and identify the needs of different communities. We feel this is an important step in building trust between researchers, public health responders and local people.”</p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                          <div class="Display--none Display--md-block"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxMjg3IiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEyODciPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiNDQkNBQzkiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                          <div class="Display--md-none"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxMjg3IiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEyODciPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiNDQkNBQzkiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                        </div>
                        <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                          <picture>
                            <!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]-->
                            <source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/HN78BsJXq6/st_mary_s_portraits_a_58_073128_001-1920x1287.jpeg">
                            <source media="(max-width: 900px)" data-srcset="./assets/HN78BsJXq6/st_mary_s_portraits_a_58_073128_001-1920x1287.jpeg">
                            <!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="./assets/HN78BsJXq6/st_mary_s_portraits_a_58_073128_001-1920x1287.jpeg" alt="Professor Helen Ward"></picture>
                        </div>
                      </div>
                      <figcaption class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                          <p class>Professor Helen Ward (Image:Jody Kingzett )</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="Display--md-none">
                          <p class>Professor Helen Ward (Image:Jody Kingzett )</p>
                        </div>
                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>Interestingly, almost half of respondents surveyed (47%) wanted to hear about the latest research on the virus, and 45% wanted a dedicated internet portal where they could access the latest information and trusted guidance.</p>
                    <p class>As a way of responding to this, J-IDEA has published a free course on COVID-19 on Coursera called <a href="https://www.coursera.org/learn/covid-19" target="_blank">Science Matters: Let's Talk about COVID-19. </a> On the course, world-class experts explain the theory behind the analyses of COVID-19 and its spread, and how to interpret new information using core principles of public health, epidemiology, medicine, health economics and social science.</p>
                    <p class>Meanwhile, UK Research and Innovation with the support of the UK Government’s Chief Scientific Adviser and Chief Medical Adviser have developed <a href="https://coronavirusexplained.ukri.org/en/" target="_blank">a portal website</a>, providing authoritative and up-to-date explanations of the scientific evidence behind the COVID-19 pandemic. It also includes links to published and pre-published scientific papers. Imperial’s Professor Neil Ferguson and Professor Ajit Lalvani are contributing editors to the website, while Dr Rhia Kundu, Dr Lucy Okell and Dr Timesh Pillay are listed as research contributors.</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay" style="opacity:0.9"></div>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section>
      <section id="group-Standing-up-k3bFe3nMje">
        <div id="Standing-up-k3bFe3nMje" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextOverMediaSection Theme-Section-Position-13 DisplayContainerHeight DisplayContainerHeight--minHeight DisplayContainerHeight--flex Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Dark Theme-Section-HasOverlay">
          <div class="Layout FullSize--fullHeight Theme-Layer-TextBlock Layer--one">

                <div>
                  <h2 class="Theme-Title Theme-TextSize-small"> Standing up for science</h2>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="Layer--two FullSize FullSize--fixedChild FullSize--child Theme-BackgroundMedia Theme-BackgroundImage">
            <div data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true" class="FullSize--fullWidth FullSize--fullHeight Core--pointerEventsNone Lazyload Lazyload--isLoading">
              <div class="FullSize Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-InstantImage" aria-hidden="true" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,">
                  <source media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" srcset="data:image/gif;base64,"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media InstantImage__img ObjectFit--cover" src="data:image/gif;base64," aria-hidden="true" width="50" height="28" alt style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
              <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                <picture class="FullSize--fullWidth DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fixedChild HideOffscreen--container Theme-Item-Picture" data-landscape-focal="50% 50%" data-portrait-focal="50% 50%">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/hvQ7QtwMih/standing-landscape-750x422.jpeg 750w, ./assets/hvQ7QtwMih/standing-landscape-1632x918.jpeg 1632w, ./assets/hvQ7QtwMih/standing-landscape-2301x1294.jpeg 2301w, ./assets/hvQ7QtwMih/standing-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg 2560w" type="image/jpeg" media="(min-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#031F32">
                  <source data-srcset="./assets/5LpUtd3AmP/standing-portrait-750x1333.jpeg 750w, ./assets/5LpUtd3AmP/standing-portrait-914x1625.jpeg 914w, ./assets/5LpUtd3AmP/standing-portrait-1065x1893.jpeg 1065w, ./assets/5LpUtd3AmP/standing-portrait-1080x1920.jpeg 1080w" type="image/jpeg" media="(max-aspect-ratio: 1/1)" sizes="100vw" style="background-color:#031F32"><img class="DisplayContainerHeight FullSize--fullWidth FullSize__fixedChild HideOffscreen__media ObjectFit--cover" data-src="./assets/hvQ7QtwMih/standing-landscape-2560x1440.jpeg" alt="Bubbles in blue liquid under the microscope" style="object-position:50% 50%"></picture>
              </div>
            </div>
            <div class="FullSize Theme-Overlay Theme-Section-Dark" style="opacity:0.3;background-color:#000000"></div>
          </div>
        </div>
        <div id="section-xeJKPLg3qf" class="Theme-Section Theme-TextSection Theme-Section-Position-14 Theme-Section-Layout--Full Theme-Section-Light Theme-BodyTextColumn-Center Theme-Section-HasOverlay Theme-Columns--1">
          <div class="Layout Layer--one">
            <div class="Layout__row">
              <div class="Layout__col Layout__col-lg-6 Layout__col-lg-center Layout__col-md-8 Layout__col-md-center Layout__col-sm-10 Layout__col-sm-center Layout__col-xs-12 Layout__col-xs-left Theme-Column">
                <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText">
                  <div class="Theme-Layer-BodyText--inner">
                    <p class="Theme-Layer-BodyText-Dropcap">The fast evolving science of the current coronavirus pandemic and the established science of climate change and the environment intersect at numerous points of interest – from the consequences of increasing proximity between humans and animals in terms of cross-species virus jumps to the alleviation of carbon emissions and air pollution from grounded flights and quiets roads during lockdown.</p>
                    <p class>There are also some interesting parallels in terms of misinformation. Most obvious is the apparent tendency in some quarters to downplay the severity or even the very existence of the pandemic in the same way some have downplayed the veracity of climate change. Both are looming threats supported by a great body of evidence, but which for many people still feel quite remote and nebulous from their own day-to-day lives. </p>
                    <p class>In many cases it’s <a href="https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2020/04/03/how-coronavirus-disinformation-gets-past-social-media-moderators/" target="_blank">the same actors</a> peddling misinformation and disinformation about both coronavirus and climate change.</p>
                    <p class>Misunderstanding about modelling is also a common strand at play here, and something climate scientists have been struggling to grapple with for many years – specifically the fact that models can produce a range of possible outcomes depending on inputs such as mitigation measures. That doesn’t mean models lack credibility and doesn’t mean there aren’t overarching certainties – such as the inevitability of health services being crippled without suppression measures or catastrophic consequences for ecosystems unless we limit global warming to an increase of 1.5 degrees or less from current levels. </p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">
                          <div class="Display--none Display--md-block"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxMjY3IiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEyNjciPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiNFMUI3MDIiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                          <div class="Display--md-none"><img alt src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTkyMCAxMjY3IiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSIxOTIwIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEyNjciPjxyZWN0IHdpZHRoPSIxMDAlIiBoZWlnaHQ9IjEwMCUiIGZpbGw9IiNFMUI3MDIiPjwvcmVjdD48L3N2Zz4=">
                            <div class="Lazyload__spiner Theme-Lazyload-Spinner"></div>
                          </div>
                        </div>
                        <div data-lazyload-item="true" class="FullSize">
                          <picture>
                            <!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]-->
                            <source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/NApooBnw7H/shutterstock_1514695385-1920x1267.jpeg">
                            <source media="(max-width: 900px)" data-srcset="./assets/NApooBnw7H/shutterstock_1514695385-1920x1267.jpeg">
                            <!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="./assets/NApooBnw7H/shutterstock_1514695385-1920x1267.jpeg" alt="Climate change banners at a rally in Germany. One sign says 'Climate is changing, why aren't you? Greenpeace'"></picture>
                        </div>
                      </div>
                      <figcaption class="Theme-Caption Theme-InlineMediaCaption">
                        <div class="Display--none Display--md-block">
                          <p class>A climate change strike demonstration in the centre of Berlin (Image: In Green / Shutterstock)</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="Display--md-none">
                          <p class>A climate change strike demonstration in the centre of Berlin (Image: In Green / Shutterstock)</p>
                        </div>
                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>Dr Nabarro previously served as Special Adviser to the UN on Sustainable Development and Climate Change. He says:</p>
                    <p class>“There’s a question around how a scientist portrays herself or himself as authoritative but at the same time being both authentic and accountable. We’re all accountable for what advice we give. I think these are constant issues for scientists. One of the things you have to do when you’re accountable is to be clear when you don’t know something, be clear why you don’t know, and be clear what might change your position. Linked to that you have to be authentic, and try and find a way to connect with your listeners, not to treat them with any kind of disrespect. These are all things that I am looking at with great interest in the current pandemic as governments and communities do their best to try to implement the guidance of the WHO in very different settings.”</p>
                    <p class>There is perhaps some hope in all of this though. The Imperial team has already published evidence that interventions in 11 European countries to counter the coronavirus pandemic, including school closures and national lockdowns, are working effectively and, that up to <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/196556/coronavirus-measures-have-already-averted-120000/" target="_blank">120,000 deaths may have already been averted.</a></p>
                    <p class>If we can demonstrate a successful, coordinated and transparent response in getting the initial coronavirus peak under control and the importance of behaviour change based on sound evidence it may help to restore more faith in the scientific process among those who are inclined to question it. That will stand us in good stead for future existential crises, such as climate change or indeed the next disease pandemic, when it inevitably comes.</p>
                    <figure class="InlineMedia InlineMedia--image" data-lazyload-container="true" data-lazyload-trigger="true">
                      <div class="InlineMedia--image__inner">
                        <div class="Lazyload__loading" aria-hidden="true">

                          <picture>

                            <source media="(min-width: 901px)" data-srcset="./assets/5aAwW4f5E7/161201_gambhir_ajay_007_209385_001-1920x1280.jpeg">

                      </figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <p class>Dr Ajay Gambhir from Imperial’s Grantham Institute – Climate Change and the Environment explored these themes <a href="https://granthaminstitute.com/2020/03/17/coronavirus-and-climate-change-there-is-much-uncertainty-and-much-to-play-for/" target="_blank">in a recent commentary about the pandemic</a>. </p>
                    <p class>He said: “The central importance of behaviour change has been brought to the fore. The ability of people and societies to respond to threats affecting their wellbeing – as is being demonstrated across the world – is a potentially powerful response mechanism. If we can heed the importance of science, behaviour change and resilient planning this would place humanity on a firmer footing to tackle the multiple challenges that we will face this century – including climate change.”</p>
                    <p class>In the meantime, we will all have to learn to live with this disease and adapt, just as we have had to do in the past.</p>
                    <p class>Dr Nabarro says: “After we learned about cholera from John Snow, we had to adapt our lives so we weren’t reliant on dirty water sources and didn’t have regular cholera outbreaks. Or 25 years ago after we learned that HIV was carried through sex and had to adapt intimacy so it was still possible despite the threat of HIV – I think humanity is amazingly resilient, so we’ll learn to live with this virus, but it’s going to be really tough at the beginning.”</p>

      var toggleVideoPlaying = function() {
        'use strict';
        var inlineVideos = document.querySelectorAll('[data-type="video/mp4"]');

        var socialTwImg = document.getElementsByClassName('Theme-TwitterIcon')[0];

        var themeLeadIn = document.getElementsByClassName('Theme-LeadIn')[0];
        var themeByLine = document.getElementsByClassName('Theme-Byline')[0];

          socialFbImg.remove();
        }
        if (socialTwImg) {
          socialTwImg.remove();
        }

        // Add custom LinkedIn share button
        var linkedInB = addLinkedInShareButton();
        // appendChild only works with nodes, not strings
        var holder = document.createElement('span');
        holder.classList.add('Theme-SocialButton');
        // Pop the string in the node
        holder.innerHTML = linkedInB;
        socialSharingContainer.appendChild(holder);

        // Move the icons somewhere (depending on whats been added/deleted by the editor)
        if (themeLeadIn && socialSharingContainer) {
          themeLeadIn.appendChild(socialSharingContainer);
        } else if (themeStoryTitle && socialSharingContainer) {
          themeStoryTitle.appendChild(socialSharingContainer);
        } else {
          // not sure where else to put it....
        }
        // Now move the byline in with the social icons 
        if (themeByLine) {
          socialSharingContainer.appendChild(themeByLine);

        var facebookShareText = document.createTextNode('Share this story on Facebook');
        if (facebookShareButton) {
          facebookShareButton.appendChild(facebookShareText);
        }

      window.addEventListener('load', function() {
        var bodyEl = document.body;
        bodyEl.classList.add('js');
        setEmptyAltsForDecorativeImages();
      });

      var addLinkedInShareButton = function() {
        var storyLink = window.location.href;
        var linkInShareUrl = "https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=";
        var linkInFullShareUrl = linkInShareUrl + storyLink;
        var linkInShareBtn = "<a class=\"Theme-LinkedInButton\" href=\"" + linkInFullShareUrl + "\">Share this story on LinkedIn</a>";

        return linkInShareBtn;
      };

      /**
       * Set empty alt tags for decorative images
       *
       */

      var setEmptyAltsForDecorativeImages = function() {
        var imgEls = document.getElementsByTagName('img');
        if (imgEls) {
          for (var i = 0; i < imgEls.length; i++) {
            var alt = imgEls[i].getAttribute('alt');

            if (!alt) {
              // Set empty alt
              imgEls[i].setAttribute('alt', '');
            }
          }
        }
      }


      // Run everything
      addTextToHeaderLinks();
      toggleVideoPlaying();
      moveSocialSharingIcons();
    </script>
